title: Button, late 18th century
medium: Gouache paint on tin verre fixé, ivory (backing), glass, gilt metal
provenance:
c. 1802: Toussaint L'Ouverture, upon return to France from Haiti and Santo Domingo gives jacket with these buttons to servant boy [1]; acquired by boy's heirs in the Sedan; Professor Lalongt, College of Sedan acquires from heirs [2]; sold to Etienne Accary; 1939: sold on behalf of Accary by Salle Drouot auction house, Paris [3]; 1949: gift to Museum from the estate of Mrs. Noyes.










[1] Given to servant boy for his loyal service to Toussaint L'Ouverture  in the prison in Besancon, France from his capture in Haiti to his death in Besancon in 1813
[2] Letter from Jean Milare tells story of servant boy and Toussaint
[3] Buttons arrive, possibly as a loan, at Cooper Union Museum around 1942
dimensions: H x diam.: 1 x 3.7 cm (3/8 x 1 7/16 in.)
creditline: Gift of R. Keith Kane from the Estate of Mrs. Robert B. Noyes
description: Button depicting scene of four figures in a landscape. Three women and a child wearing dresses. At center a light-skinned woman in jewelry and large turban topped with a sunhat.

tombstone.epitaph: Button, late 18th century.Gouache paint on tin verre fixé, ivory (backing), glass, gilt metal. Gift of R. Keith Kane from the Estate of Mrs. Robert B. Noyes. 1949-94-18.
